<html><body><div><div class="" data-article-body="true"><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Canberra has formally protested against the penalties slapped on those responsible for the deadly methanol poisoning of two young Australian women in Laos.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Holly Morton-Bowles and Bianca Jones, both aged 19, died after they were served alcohol laced with methanol at Nana Backpacker Hostel in November 2024.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Two Danish women, a US tourist and a British woman also died.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Last month, 10 staff were found guilty of destroying evidence, with each person receiving a suspended sentence and a $185 fine.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">No further charges will be laid but a man from the distillery where the spirits were made could face legal action.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">The action came after a lengthy police investigation and has sparked outrage from the families of the victims, who have demanded Labor ramp up diplomatic pressure on Laos.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Sussan Ley kicked off Question Time on Tuesday by asking what the Albanese government would do.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“As a mother I was devastated to see the fathers of Bianca Jones and Holly Morton-Bowles front the media today following revelations that those responsible for the deaths of their girls have received fines of just $185,” the Opposition Leader said.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“The families had to learn this from a British victim’s family. Government officials have apologised today.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“What action will the Prime Minister now take to seek justice for these beautiful girls?”</p><figure class="relative mb-4"><figcaption class="relative text-sm mt-1 pr-2.5"><p>Prime Minister Anthony Albanese says his government has protested the penalties. Picture: NewsWire / Martin Ollman</p></figcaption></figure><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Thanking Ms Ley for her question, Anthony Albanese said the deaths were “an absolute tragedy”.</p><p class="mb-4"></p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“All our hearts go out to the loved ones and friends of Holly Morton-Bowles and Bianca Jones,” he said.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“Like so many young Australians do, they set off overseas together for fun and adventure to expand their horizons in the world.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“What occurred is an absolute tragedy.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“They should be with us today looking back on a trip full of happy memories made together.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“Instead their loved ones are still mourning a devastating loss.”</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">The Prime Minister went on to say revelations of the penalties and how the families learned of them “have added to the heart break of their families”.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has apologised unreservedly for their failure to ensure that the families were informed and that is an entirely appropriate thing for them to do,” Mr Albanese said.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“The Foreign Minister’s made it clear to her counterpart in Laos that Australia expects full accountability and the charges should reflect the devastating seriousness of this incident.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“Six lives that were lost, including Holly and Bianca’s, and we will continue to engage Laos authorities on these cases and everything we and ban can’s families at this distressing time.”</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words"><b>‘Every day is tough’</b></p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">The girls’ fathers, Shaun Bowles and Mark Jones, earlier on Tuesday revealed they were not kept in the loop during a court case at The People’s Court of Vang Vieng.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Speaking to the Nine’s <i>Today Show</i>, Mr Jones said the outcome was “devastating”.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“Every day is tough, and when you get news that we received last week that our daughter’s lives are valued at $185 it’s pretty devastating,” Mr Jones said through tears.</p><figure class="relative mb-4"><figcaption class="relative text-sm mt-1 pr-2.5"><p>Holly Morton-Bowles and Bianca Jones were both aged 19. Picture: Supplied</p></figcaption></figure><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Mr Bowles said that his family found out about the fines through the parents of British backpacker Simone White – who also died from methanol poisoning at the hostel at the same time as Holly and Bianca.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“Simone’s father Neil sent us through a message that he got from the British authorities and passed it on to all of us,” Mr Bowles explained.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“Unfortunately that’s how we found out about the outcome.”</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Mr Bowles said that given six people died as a result of the mass methanol poisoning, for fines of just $185 to be distributed was a complete “disappointment”.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“To think that the Laos authorities believe that those who were involved in killing our daughters is worth $185 is absolutely disgraceful,” Mr Jones said.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“We can’t get into the country. There’s nothing more we can do. We need the government to do something because we are out of options,” Mr Bowles said.</p><figure class="relative mb-4"><figcaption class="relative text-sm mt-1 pr-2.5"><p>The father of Bianca Jones has expressed outrage over the fines. Picture: Supplied</p></figcaption></figure><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words"><b>Canberra reacts</b></p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Foreign Minister Penny Wong said the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade had been in regular communication with the families.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“I have made it clear to my Lao counterpart that Australia expects full accountability,” Senator Wong said.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“I have also made it clear that charges should reflect the seriousness of the tragedy which left six people dead, including Holly and Bianca.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade is aware that the Vang Vieng District Court sentenced individuals over the destruction of evidence in relation to the death of a US citizen.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“We continue to press Lao authorities on the cases relating to Holly and Bianca’s deaths, and we will continue to support Holly and Bianca’s families at this distressing time.”</p><figure class="relative mb-4"><figcaption class="relative text-sm mt-1 pr-2.5"><p>Bianca Jones and Holly Bowles died from methanol poisoning in Laos. Picture: 60 Minutes</p></figcaption></figure><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Opposition foreign affairs spokeswoman Michaelia Cash echoed the families in a statement demanding Mr Albanese “immediately summon the Laotian ambassador”.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“Australians are rightly shocked,” she said.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“Four other tourists, two Danish women, a US tourist and a British woman, also died in this mass poisoning event.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“A year ago we learned the Laos government was refusing Australian Federal Police assistance in the investigation.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“A year ago Australians were told by the Albanese government that the matter was in hand.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“At the time the leader made the point on Channel 7’s Sunrise.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“We now know there has been no meaningful justice for Holly and Bianca, and their families did not learn of these outcomes from their own government but via the British woman’s family.”</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">Senator Cash added that Australia “makes a significant contribution to Laos through our foreign aid program and other development assistance”.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“The Albanese government should remind the Laotian government of the important contributions Australian taxpayers make to key programs in Laos in-line with the friendship between our two countries.</p><p class="mb-4 text-lg md:leading-8 break-words">“It is in that same spirit of friendship and co-operation that Australians rightly have an expectation of proper justice and accountability for the deaths of two young Australians.”</p></div></div></body></html>
